title: Property loan fund to launch in P2P boom
text:
Property loan fund to launch in P2P boom Judith Evans Comments 
The online loan platform LendInvest is to launch a listed fund, the first such vehicle to focus on property-backed peer-to-peer lending. 
The launch comes as peer-to-peer investment trusts prove hugely popular with income-hungry investors, raising more than £1.2bn since the first such fund launched last year. More Backlash over ousting of fund body chief 
LendInvest is seeking to raise £150m for the float of the London-listed fund, according to people familiar with the launch. 
It will target an eight per cent annual yield, mainly through loans made on the LendInvest platform, which currently consist of bridging loans of up to 36 months secured against residential properties. 
It will also hold equity in the platform itself, which hopes to list on the main London market and originated £250m of loans in the financial year 2014-15. 
LendInvest aims to launch the fund early next year, depending on market conditions. 
“A listed fund is an attractive proposition and one that would make a lot of sense for our business,” the company said. 
LendInvest lends to professional landlords and says it currently commands 10 per cent of the UK short-term mortgage market, with average loan terms of seven to eight months. 
LendInvest was spun out of the real estate investment business Montello Capital Management, which already runs two unlisted funds investing in its bridging loans. 
Funding Circle, the largest P2P platform for business lending, is also raising money for its own listed fund. 
China’s Beijing Kunlun backs UK peer-to-peer lender LendInvest 
Chinese investors are turning to international peer-to-peer lending platforms in search of higher returns, as competition in the fast-growing alternative finance sector heats up. Beijing Kunlun, a Chinese-listed technology company, has struck a deal to back British P2P platform LendInvest with a £22m investment. 
Read more 
The existing alternative lending investment trusts — P2P Global Investments, VPC Specialty Lending, and Ranger Direct Lending — are all trading at premiums; the largest, P2P Global Investments, is currently yielding 4.6 per cent. Lendinvest has not so far given these funds access to its platform. 
Property loans are one of the fastest-growing segments in the booming lending industry, which has originated almost £2bn of loans in the year to date. 
But some commentators have cautioned over the speed of its expansion. John Spiers, who founded the online investment supermarket Bestinvest, warned this week that the sector’s credit standards needed to be tested through a full market cycle. 
“Peer-to-peer is fundamentally a great idea, but it would be good for it to evolve a bit more slowly. It hasn’t got that history through a crisis period,” he said. 
LendInvest, which is itself profitable and closed a £22m Series A funding round in June, has experienced bad debt but has carried out successful recoveries of the underlying assets on behalf of investors.
